title: Fountains Fell Walk Route

images.title: Gordon Hatton / Fountains Fell summit plateau
images.caption: Fountains Fell summit plateau. Near the highest point of the fell with Pen y Ghent in the middle distance and Ingleborough beyond.

images.title: William Bartlett / Fountains Fell Tarn
images.caption: Walkers on  Fountains Fell Tarn. After a very dry start to April, the tarn is surrounded by dry grass and moss. The shallow brackish water though is still too cold, and shallow, to tempt swimmers but proves a popular place to skim the flat stones found in plenty along the shoreline.

images.title: Signpost on The Pennine Way by Tom Richardson, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Signpost on The Pennine Way

images.title: William Bartlett / Fountains Fell
images.caption: Looking down the wall towards the T junction of walls you can see Malham Tarn in the distance on the left. Fountains Fell Tarn is a little way behind the photographer as are the strange landforms at the top of this fell. The wall has recently been restored.

images.title: William Bartlett / Fountains Fell
images.caption: The bowl central to this wide angle of Fountains Fell shows the open expanse of the Fell with the Pennine way running along the top

images.title: William Bartlett / Fountains Fell
images.caption: Streams coming off to the right of the derelict house, run down to form Fornah Gill. This is Fountains Fell moorland and used for grouse shooting.

images.title: William Bartlett / Follow the Wall to Fountains Fell
images.caption: Follow the Wall. The moorland that separates Fountains Fell (in the distance) and Penyghent (behind photographer) is mostly grouse moor with some sheep and cattle farming closer to the road that runs across the valley. Photograph centred on the right turn in the wall that is in lower centre of picture

images.title: William Bartlett / Moughton wall junction
images.caption: Moughton wall junction. Looking across from limestone pavement at a wall intersection. On the other side of the Ribble Valley is Penyghent and Fountains Fell on the horizon

description: Climb to this prominent fell in the Yorkshire Dales and enjoy wonderful views over the surrounding hills and countryside. The circular walk starts from the beautiful Malham Tarn and climbs to the fell using a section of the Pennine Way National Trail. The route climbs to a height of 668 metres (2,192 ft) with lovely views of the pretty Fountains Fell Tarn below. At the northern tip of the route you have the option of following the Pennine Way north west to Pen y ghent , one of the famous three peaks of Yorkshire. To extend your walking in the area you can explore the Malham Tarn estate with its glacial lake and Tarn Moss Nature Reserve. There's also the climb to Gordale Scar , the fascinating Malham Cove and the beautiful Janet's Foss waterfall to visit on the estate. The route of the Settle Loop also passes just to the south west of the fell.
